title: Problem Overview
content: This module formalizes **Erdős Problem #350**: If A is a finite dissociated set (all subset sums distinct), prove that the sum of reciprocals is less than 2.
mathContext: The problem was SOLVED by Ryavec. The bound is sharp: powers of 2 achieve equality in the limit. Hanson-Steele-Stenger (1977) generalized to all positive exponents.

title: Dissociated Sets
content: **DistinctSubsetSums A** means all subsets of A have distinct sums. For any X ≠ Y subsets of A, we require ΣX ≠ ΣY.
mathContext: A dissociated set (also called a B-sequence) with n elements has 2^n distinct subset sums. The canonical example is {1, 2, 4, ..., 2^k} whose subset sums are exactly 0, 1, 2, ..., 2^{k+1}-1.

title: Singleton is Dissociated
content: **singleton_one_dissociated**: The singleton {1} is trivially dissociated. Its only subsets are ∅ (sum 0) and {1} (sum 1), which are distinct.
mathContext: This is proved by case analysis on subsets. A singleton {a} has only two subsets with sums 0 and a, always distinct for positive a.

title: Powers of 2 are Dissociated
content: **powers_of_two_dissociated**: The set {1, 2, 4, ..., 2^k} is dissociated. This is the canonical example of a dissociated set.
mathContext: Every natural number has a unique binary representation, so subset sums of powers of 2 are all distinct. This set achieves the extremal bound in Ryavec's theorem.

title: Ryavec's Theorem (Main Result)
content: **erdos_350**: If A is a finite dissociated set of positive integers, then Σ_{n∈A} 1/n < 2. This is the core result of Erdős Problem #350.
mathContext: The proof, reproduced in Benkoski-Erdős 1974, uses properties of dissociated sets and their subset sums. The bound 2 comes from the geometric series of powers of 2.

title: Ryavec's Sharp Bound
content: **ryavec_sharp_bound**: Σ 1/n ≤ 2 - 2^{1-|A|}, with equality iff A = {1, 2, ..., 2^k}. This characterizes the extremal dissociated sets.
mathContext: For {1,2,...,2^k}, the sum is 1 + 1/2 + ... + 1/2^k = 2 - 2^{-k} = 2 - 2^{1-(k+1)}. As k → ∞, this approaches but never reaches 2.

title: Hanson-Steele-Stenger Generalization
content: **hanson_steele_stenger**: For all s > 0, Σ 1/n^s < 1/(1 - 2^{-s}). This extends Ryavec's bound to all positive exponents.
mathContext: At s = 1: 1/(1 - 1/2) = 2, recovering Ryavec. At s = 2: 1/(1 - 1/4) = 4/3. The bound comes from geometric series with ratio 2^{-s}.

title: Subset Closure
content: **dissociated_subset**: Any subset of a dissociated set is also dissociated. This is a basic closure property.
mathContext: Proof: If X, Y ⊆ B ⊆ A and X ≠ Y, then X, Y ⊆ A and by A being dissociated, ΣX ≠ ΣY. Hence B is dissociated.

title: Sidon Sets
content: **IsSidonSet A**: All pairwise sums a+b (with a ≤ b) are distinct. Every dissociated set is a Sidon set, but not conversely.
mathContext: Sidon sets (B₂ sequences) only require pairwise sums to be distinct. Dissociated sets require ALL subset sums to be distinct - much stronger. Example: {1, 2, 5, 10} is Sidon but not dissociated (1+5 = 2+4 as subset sums).

title: Numerical Examples
mathContext: These examples show the bound in action. For powers of 2 up to 2^k, the sum is 2 - 2^{-k}, always strictly less than 2.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_350_summary** packages the key verified results: {1, 2} is dissociated, and 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8 < 2.
mathContext: This summary demonstrates the formalization captures both the definition (dissociated sets) and the bound (sum of reciprocals < 2).
